start-form.title: Norovirus Genotyping Tool Version 0.9
start-form.note:
This tool is designed to use phylogenetic methods in order to identify the norovirus genotype of a nucleotide sequences.
Note for batch analysis: The genotypetool accepts up to {1} sequences at a time.

howToCite-form.title: How to Cite the Norovirus Automated Genotyping Tool

text.p: Norovirus genotyping tool, National Institute of Public health and the Environment, The Netherlands, www.rivm.nl.

The sequence report contains a brief overview of the assignment, followed by details that up to four phylogenetic analyses, depending on the length and positioning, and on the assigned genotype of the input sequence.

The Sequence assignment contains information on:
the sequence submitted (name and length),
the classification assignment for ORF1 and ORF2
the motivation of the classifications, including the bootstrap value
a graphical representation of the Norovirus genome showing the genomic region of the query sequence with the start and end positions with respect to the NC_001959 genome,

ORF1 and ORF2 are always analyzed separately. Only a part (700 nucleotides at the 3' end) of ORF1 (region A and B) can be used for genotyping, while the entire ORF2 (which includes regions C, D, and E) is supported.
Genome
Only when your sequence has sufficient overlap (>100 bps) with each of these areas, a phylogenetic analysis is performed for that area.

For the II.4 genotype an additional variant analysis is performed, while for some other II genotypes in ORF1, a variant analysis is performed resulting in the suggestion of a likely matching ORF2 genotype.

Each phylogenetic analysis section contains:
a picture of the phylogenetic tree, which can be downloaded in PDF and Nexus format,
the log file generated by PAUP (contains info on the model of evolution and its parameters),
the alignment used.

text.b: The genotyping process consists of up to three steps:

ol.li:
The initial step performs an amino-acid blast scan to identify the genogroup and the approximate regions covered by the fragment. The submitted sequence is blasted against a set of 6 whole genome sequences (Genbank: NC_001959, X86557, U07611, AF097917, AF414426, NC_008311).
Schematic representation of genomic regions of NoV used for genotyping, adapted from: Vinje J, Hamidjaja RA, Sobsey MD. Development and application of a capsid VP1 (region D) based reverse transcription PCR assay for genotyping of genogroup I and II noroviruses. J Virol Methods 2004; 116(2):109-17.
The numbering is relative to the NC_001959 genome.

li.p: For Genogroups I and II, for each region (ORF1 fragment or ORF2) supported by tool, that overlaps sufficiently with the submitted sequence, a phylogenetic tree is constructed using the HKY851 method in the PAUP*2 software. The alignment contains the sequence together with reference sequences for each genotype. Also a bootstrap tree is computed using 100 replicates, presented in the PAUP* log file. For each genotype two representative sequences have been selected, representing the level of variance within the cluster. One of these sequences is usually the official reference strain, while the other sequence is a more contemporary strain.
A successful assigment requires a bootstrap value over 70.

When a genotype II.4 could be identified, a second analysis is done with several sequences of that genotype to identify a specific variant. The same phylogenetic method is used as in step 2, using again 2 representative strains per subcluster.
For particular genotypes in ORF1, a second analysis is done with several sequences of that genotype that represent a sub-cluster with a likely capside variant.

p.div: 1 Hasegawa M, Kishino H, Yano T: Dating of the human-ape splitting by a molecular clock of mitochondrial DNA. J Mol Evol 1985, 22:160-174.
2 Wilgenbusch JC, Swofford D. Inferring evolutionary trees with PAUP*. Curr Protoc Bioinformatics 2003;Chapter 6:Unit 6.4.
